title: The first chapter of my novel is much shorter than other chapters. Should I make it a prologue? It also doesn't focus on the main character as much but is still essential to the plot and his story. - Quora

response.answer_text: Sure. Just make certain the prologue stuff is interesting and grabs the reader. It’s misleading to promise the reader one story but start off with an aside. Remember the movie “The Princess Bride”. It doesn’t open in Fairy Tale Land, it opens with a kid playing a video game and his grandfather walks in. That was supposed to establish the narrative. Instead it had the audience buzzing, “Hey, what? Did I walk into the wrong theater? Oh, crap…” And they couldn’t enjoy the sequence. You might consider putting the “prologue” after the first chapter as an “interlude”. That way you introduce your main character, get the reader hooked with their challenge, then stop for a moment and go, “OK, you need to know this stuff before reading further…” Or toss it entirely and work it in later. Hemingway said, “When writing a short story, throw away the first page. When writing a book, throw away the first chapter.” Sounds like what you might have here.

My gut reaction is: “No. No prologues!” Few authors do them well. But maybe you’re the exception. I’d recommend leaving out the short chapter entirely. Don’t delete, just set it aside. Then let your editor and beta readers have the rest of the ms. Don’t mention the missing chapter. If the feedback makes it clear that the missing information is actually essential, then discuss the missing chapter with your editor. It may be it’s perfect prologue material, but more likely that essential info can be cannibalized into other parts of the narrative where it will do its work most effectively.
